They develop their ideas effectively, with specific details, such as the dialogue between the protagonist and mom, the allowance, the retail, and the learning process. Thus, the student's work warrants a score of 6 for ideas.

The story's organization is sufficient, but it could be improved. The events are logically sequenced as the student builds on the initial interest in makeup, leading to the purchase and the practice. However, the connection between some ideas is not very clear, such as the importance of the protagonist's sister in relation to patience, and the abrupt transition concerning the protagonist's first try in applying makeup. Therefore, the organization merits a score of 2. 

In terms of style, the student's language and sentence structure are clear and support the writer's purpose. The command of language is adequate, but the word choice and variety in sentence structure are lacking in certain areas. There is also an overuse of quotes that sometimes hampers the clarity of the narrative. As a result, the student achieves a score of 2 for style.

Regarding conventions, the student's response displays adequate use of Standard English. However, there are a few issues with punctuation, most noticeably the overuse of quotation marks and a couple run-on sentences. The usage of @signs also hampers the clarity of the reading, which could be a typing-related error. Consequently, they warrant a score of 2 for conventions. 

To summarize, the student's understanding of patience is well-demonstrated in a clear story with a consistently focused theme. However, the organization, style, and conventions could use improvement, particularly in terms of clearer transitions, varied sentence structures, and better punctuation use.

SCORE: 12/15

essay: Patience is something that people don't have sometimes. I know I did once. And I 'm gonna tell you about it. It was a bright sunny day. All my family members were outside. My dad making hot dogs and hamburgers in the grill. My mom setting up the table. And me and my sibling playing catch with a football. All of us knew how to throw and catch a football but not my little brother. Considering the fact that all of us were chose to teach my little brother. We tried once, we tried twice, but he just wouldn't get the hang of it. Finally all my sisters got tired of explaining him the object of the game, so they gave up. Me, on the other side said it over and over until he understood it. I myself got tired of telling him over and what to do. But then I thought 'hey give the kid a chance he might just get it 'so I just kept on helping him. "@CAPS1 is ready! Come inside", my mom had called out. "Time for @CAPS1 lets go inside" I said to my little brother. "@CAPS2! Just one last time, I promise I will get it!" he exclaimed. "@CAPS3, but just one time" I responded. Even tho he had been saying that the past few hundred times he'd tried, I thought it wouldn't hurt to do it once more. As I released the ball from hands my brother ran up to it and caught it! After he caught it he shouted "I did it" and I looked at him proudly and said "good job" he ran inside to tell my parents that he finally caught it. I was really alod that I had token the time to help him. I knew he could do it @CAPS2 matter how many times I tried or he tried. I knew he would get it soon. And he did! And that was the time I was patient.

However, the story could benefit from better transition phrases to create a smoother flow between ideas. Therefore, the student would score a 2 for organization. 

In 'Style', the student demonstrates a satisfactory command of language that supports their purpose, but has limited variation in sentence structure.
